title: A Randomized Pivotal Study of RenewTM NCP-5 for the Treatment of Mild Cognitive Impairment Due to Alzheimer's Disease or Mild Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: A Randomized Pivotal Study of RenewTM NCP-5 for the Treatment of Mild Cognitive Impairment due to Alzheimer's Disease or Mild Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type is a pivotal, single blind, parallel design, multi-site study intends to examine the efficacy and safety of RenewTM NCP-5 therapy in the treatment of Cognitive Impairment due to Alzheimer's Disease or Mild Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type. Subjects will be prospectively randomized to treatment or sham (in a 1:1 ratio) using stratification for Cognitive Impairment due to Alzheimer's Disease or Mild Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type, and Cardiovascular Risk (CVR) score at multiple sites. Subjects, ages 55-85, will be consented for 13 months and will receive thirty-five 60-minute RenewTM NCP-5 treatment sessions during a 7-to-12-week initial treatment period, and then transition to a lower frequency maintenance period (twice a week) for a total treatment period of 24 weeks.

groups.title: Treatment Arm
groups.description:
The first four sessions will be the escalation phase using the Renew NCP-5. There will be a 5-minute ramp up period where the pressure is increased 1 psi/min until the desired pressure is reached. The goal for the treatment group will be at least 2.5 psi for the first treatment, and then escalate the pressure gradually through the fourth session with an average goal of 3 psi/session. After the fourth session, the pressure will be slowly increased to reach the maximum level the subject can tolerate with a goal of reaching 3-6 psi.

Renew NCP-5: Treatment will be given 3-5 times a week for a total of 35 treatments over 12 weeks.

groups.title: Sham Arm
groups.description:
The subjects will receive the same initial and maintenance treatment regimen on the Renew NCP-5. The pressure will not exceed an average of 0.5 psi over all treatments.

Renew NCP-5: Treatment will be given 3-5 times a week for a total of 35 treatments over 12 weeks.

dropWithdraws.type: Early Termination Due to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) due to AD

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline to 24 Weeks in Vascular Dementia Assessment Scale Cognitive Subscale (vADAS-cog) Using the Average of Scores at 12, 18 and 24 Weeks.
outcomeMeasures.description: The vADAS-cog assessment includes 17 subscale scores. The total score is the sum of all scaled scored from 0-120. The higher values represent more cognitive impairment. The change in vADAS-cog scores from baseline at the timepoints of 12, 18, and 24 weeks is averaged together for each patient. The primary outcome measure is the average of those values for all patients in a group.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: There were 7 treatment and 11 active sham with missing VADAS-cog values at 12, 18, and 24 weeks. These 18 subjects with all 3 primary time points missing discontinued the study. These values were multiply imputed from the longitudinal model as pre-specified.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants With Treatment Related Adverse Events as Assessed by MedDRA.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: 3 participants from active sham group were migrated to treatment group.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: The period from signing informed consent to the end of the study treatment follow-up (Month 12).
adverseEventsModule.description: 3 participants from active sham group were migrated to treatment group.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described (RenewTM NCP-5) is a device — an External Counterpulsation (ECP) system — intended to improve vascular/hemodynamic function, not a biologic or small-molecule drug. citeturn0search6turn0search3

Act (trial details extracted): The pivotal randomized trial compares active RenewTM NCP-5 versus sham, delivering thirty-five 60-minute initial sessions followed by a maintenance regimen; the primary outcome is change in cognitive score (vADAS‑Cog). citeturn0search9turn0search5

Mechanism: ECP is reported to alter cerebral hemodynamics and cerebral blood flow, and the trial includes neuroimaging (ASL CBF) to assess mechanistic engagement — the device aims to improve cognition via improved vascular perfusion rather than directly targeting AD molecular pathology. citeturn0search8

Classification rationale (Reflect): The device is neither a biologic nor a small molecule and is intended to improve cognitive function through vascular/hemodynamic effects. Under the provided category definitions, this most closely fits 'cognitive enhancer' (intervention improving cognition without directly targeting amyloid/tau pathology). There is a possible disease-modifying hypothesis via vascular improvement, but that does not change the best-fit category given the definitions. citeturn0search8turn0search9

Web search sources used: Renew NCP-5 product/indication and FAQ (Renew™ site); trial design and rationale (Alzheimer's & Dementia / Moriarty et al.); neuroimaging & CBF mechanistic description (Salat et al., Alzheimer's & Dementia); clinical trial registry/locations (ICHGCP/MedPath). citeturn0search6turn0search9turn0search8turn0search4turn0search5
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is Renew™ NCP-5, an External Counterpulsation (ECP) device intended to improve vascular/hemodynamic function and cerebral blood flow rather than directly acting on amyloid, tau, synapses, or inflammation. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Trial details extracted from the study description — a randomized, single-blind, sham-controlled pivotal trial comparing active Renew™ NCP-5 versus sham with an initial bolus of thirty-five 60-minute sessions followed by maintenance; primary outcome is change in vADAS‑Cog and ASL CBF is included as a mechanistic imaging endpoint. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: Given CADRO categories, the most specific match is K) Vasculature because the device targets cerebral perfusion/hemodynamics (vascular mechanisms). It is not a pharmacologic agent targeting molecular AD pathology (amyloid, tau, inflammation, etc.), nor does the intervention indicate multiple distinct biological targets that would justify R) Multi-target. Clinical imaging and prior reports support a vascular/hemodynamic mechanism of action. citeturn0search2turn0search6

Web search results (key sources used): Moriarty et al., design/rationale for Renew™ NCP-5 pivotal study (Alzheimer's & Dementia). citeturn0search0; Salat et al., neuroimaging methods describing ASL CBF and vascular rationale. citeturn0search2; Renew™ product/indication page (NCP-5 ECP device, FDA-cleared indications for vascular use). citeturn0search3; MedPath / trial listing with regimen and endpoints. citeturn0search1; JACC report of ECP performance in MCI/mild AD supporting vascular/CBF effects. citeturn0search4
